description: A substantial Romano-Celtic temple set within an extensive temenos, 1km east of the Roman town. The site shows some evidence of pre-invasion use in the early 1st century as a possible late Iron Age shrine and shows continued ritual activity up to the the late 4th or early 5th century.
bibliography: Alaimo, K., (2016), An Archaeology of Temple Assemblages and Social Practice in Early South-Eastern Roman Britain
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Great Chesterford Temple (Essex), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Medlycott, (2011), The Roman Town of Great Chesterford, East Anglian Archaeology, 137
Smith, A., (2008), The Fate of Pagan Temples in South-East Britain, in Ritual Landsacpes of South-East Britain
(1963), Essex, in Victoria County History, 3, pg. 82
Nash-Williams, A., Nash-Williams, V., (1935), Essex, in Catalogue of the Roman Inscribed and Sculptured Stones found at Caerleon, Royal Commission on Historical Monuments, 23
Neville, R., (1848), in Sepulchra Exposita, pg. 89
